contentrichtext.text: '''Father Hendricks''' (18?? - June 1906) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[Roman Catholic]] [[missionary]].<ref>Peter Hopkirk, ''Foreign Devils on the Silk Road: The Search for the Lost Cities and Treasures of Chinese Central Asia''. Amherst: The [[University of Massachusetts Press]]. ISBN 0-87023-435-8, 1980</ref><ref>Oscar Terry Crosby, [http://www.archive.org/stream/tibetturkestanjo00crosrich/tibetturkestanjo00crosrich_djvu.txt TIBET AND TURKESTAN - A JOURNEY THROUGH OLD LANDS AND A STUDY OF NEW CONDITIONS], 1905</ref> Accompanied by a Polish nobleman called Adam Ignatovich whom he had met in [[Omsk]] on his way to [[Chinese Turkestan]],<ref>John Avetaranian, Richard Schafer and John Bechard, "A Muslim who became a Christian", 2003, page 83</ref> Hendricks arrived in [[Kashgar]] in 1885 and remained there until his death. During his stay in Kashgar, Hendricks clashed with [[Nikolai Petrovsky]], the Russian consul-general, and lived for a time with [[George Macartney (British consul)|George Macartney]] at [[Chini-Bagh]].<ref name="dsr.nii.ac.jp">"[http://dsr.nii.ac.jp/toyobunko/VIII-5-B2-8/V-1/ Ruins of Desert Cathay - Personal Narrative of Explorations in Central Asia and Westernmost China]", Volume 1, [[Aurel Stein|M A Stein]], 1907, p. 124</ref> Hendricks frequently had to travel to [[Presidencies and provinces of British India|British India]], and despite good relations with Macartney, he occasionally had troubles crossing the border. British agent [[Ralph Cobbold]] reported that in the late 1890s Hendriks was detained by the British for several weeks at [[Hunza (princely state)|Hunza]] on the border with [[Xinjiang]].<ref name=cobbold>[[Ralph P. Cobbold]]. [http://books.google.com/books?id=GbCDC3PqfGwC Innermost Asia - Travels and Sport in the Pamirs]. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, 1900. pp. 232-34</ref> Hendricks ran his church out of a mud hut and was apparently able to only convert one person, a Chinese cobbler, during his time in Kashgar.<ref name="dsr.nii.ac.jp"/> Father Hendricks died of throat [[cancer]] and was carried to his grave by a [[Cossack]] escort.<ref name="dsr.nii.ac.jp"/> ==References== {{reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Hendricks, Father | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1907 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hendricks, Father}} [[Category:1907 deaths]] [[Category:Christian missionaries in Central Asia]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]]
